body: This seems to not interfere too much with my own DST branch (where I did a similar change to coercions to have both `a` and `b` shallow resolutions in the same place).

I'm wondering if we want the lints to default to warn, in the absence of type ascription? I guess it is very rare to need to convert to a trait object, and one can typically use an intermediate variable, and that seems like the only case where one might _require_ a cast today (other than the trivial numeric case, which is already separated). I agree that the lint names seem wrong.
Yeah, should be `&x` in the examples
Type ascription doesn't let you do any more, it is just more convenient, given there's an implementation that just needs rebasing and an accepted RFC, I would expect it to land very soon in any case.
:scream_cat: `c2fde5a` is not a valid commit SHA. Please try again with `c4f3029`.
:hourglass: Trying commit c4f3029 with merge d8f41c5...
:hourglass: Trying commit a7b6af9 with merge ce76bff...
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #23654) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

@nrc how would you feel about making the `trivial_numeric_casts` lint allow-by-default? Right now if you're using a libc type you don't actually know what the definition is (e.g. `libc::time_t`) so it's casted into an `i64` so we know what it is. This conversion, though, is a trivial cast on some platforms (but not necessarily on all platforms).
I just filed #23739 requesting that `trivial_numeric_casts` ignore casts between types that are type aliases. This was motivated by `libc` types.
Ah, breaking change needs to be exactly  `[breaking-change]` (with hyphen) to show up in the live list, so this didn't.
